job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hatfield, East of England, England
pros: The University is a good place to work and can be good at rewarding their staff. The standard hours are 8.30-5.00 Monday to Thursday and 8.30-4.00 Fridays. This is not true for every position but for most. Good annual leave including bank holidays (if full time) and closure between xmas and new year (only beneficial for substantive staff). UH offers flexi time (not for every dept), cycle to work, xmas party and small xmas bonus in the form of usually John Lewis vouchers. Every department/school has it's own merits and secondments opportunities become available quite often. It's easy to move around within your pay scale to gain experience.
cons:
Some departments can be very strict on structure and lack of reward for it's staff. It can be hit or miss depending on where you work (and I have worked in quite a few across the Uni). There is a constant underlying issue of 'Academic vs Professional' and how Academics are rewarded better, ie. can move up the scale without stopping at a bar unlike professional, more annual leave. 

Same issue with most large companies, Management seem to not be aware of what the 'Admin' staff do and make decisions without understanding the effects.

job_title: International Business Development Manager in London, England
pros: Great campus, teachers, and facilities.
cons: It is not located in London.

job_title: Forensic Analyst in London, England

review_title: Interesting work mired by overly bureacratic departments
job_title: User Computing Development Consultant in Hatfield, East of England, England
pros: Flexible working, good holidays, sense of achievement if your job entails contact with end users (students / lecturers etc.)
cons: Overly bureaucratic environment, where meetings happen for the sake of it, rather than with any clear purpose / accountability / direction. Expectation to still meet deadlines (that you have no influence over) and to attend all meetings (that you have no influence over the frequency of, or the number you're conscripted onto), with no overtime. Managers are paralysed from being able to make decisions due to too many layers of management (no single layer of management can make a decision on its own, seemingly, forming a combination lock & delay / barrier to any progress).

review_title: School of Humanities Student Representative Officer 2011-2012
job_title: Student School Representative Officer in Hatfield, East of England, England
pros: part of the SU community and the University as a whole.  Got to meet important people such as the vice chancellor, CEO and the dean of the University on a regular basis to discuss any improvements, comments or suggestions on behalf of the Student body.
cons: Only met up once a month, so if you couldn't make that meeting you miss out on a lot of important discussions. Only 1 year posts with no option to continue the next.

job_title: Group Leader in Hatfield, East of England, England

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Hatfield, East of England, England
